author: T
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2021
review_content: I preordered this before it's release date so this review is long overdue. Having been a fan of previous Animal Crossing games, I was super excited for this one! The game itself is fun and cute, but it is not perfect. Compared to previous games, you can essentially decorate your entire island however you want. There are also a lot more customization options. What I think can most be improved is the "quality of life". There are just some little details that can improve the game play such as faster and more convenient island building features and unlimited shopping cart for shops for fast check out. There's a great video on YouTube about quality of life improvement suggestions for this game that makes me wish Nintendo sees.The prices to move buildings is INSANE but it's a game. But what I think definitely needs to improve is the multi-player option. I wish there's also an option to use two remotes for the 2nd player and for them to have the same power as the 1st. It's annoying having to switch off to access inventories. I also think a split screen should be implemented for multi-player use (think Mario Kart) so that the players can have fun building the island together. DIY gets annoying and getting recipes or good furniture takes forever, but the game IS fun. It's relaxing and a great way to kill some time. The game also gets regular updates so there's still hope for some improvements.
title: More like 4.5

author: CrimsonSandBoa (Megan Hancock)
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2021
review_content: As a fan of Animal Crossing: New Leaf, I can happily say that this is an amazing game. It gives off the same relaxing vibe as the others, with some new and great ideas.First of all, the improvement to the controls gives you some serious quality of life. Being able to quickly switch between your items with the wheel is a grand idea, and I hope whoever thought of this at Nintendo received a raise. I love it, everyone loves it, and we love you. Plus, they took notes from Animal Crossing: Happy Home Designer with how you can arrange your furniture. It makes decorating rooms much more interesting and less frustrating.The graphics, of course, have improved from the last game. New Horizons is very pleasing to the eye. Nighttime is my favorite because the sky looks phenomenal, and I adore waiting to see a shooting star. Not only that, but they have vastly improved the graphics on clothes you can create! I find myself far more tempted to snag outfits from creators now that they're not so extremely pixilated.Lastly, the ways you can customize your island are endless. There is now terraforming. TERRAFORMING!! You can do almost anything to your island thanks to terraforming! I've seen so much creativity from people with this one tool. Plus, items can now be displayed outdoors however you want. Would you like a couch on the beach? That's weird, but go ahead! The freedom is endless.TLDR: New Horizons is a vast improvement on New Leaf, a game I already loved as is. Get it if you haven't yet. Enjoy yourself. Be creative. Relax.
title: A Relaxing, Wonderful Time

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2021
review_content: Latest update: i am knocking off a star. Just upgraded the town hall and now that Isabelle is here, the background music is unbearably loud for me and the game doesn't have any way to adjust the sound. I have medical conditions that make loud music painful. Furthermore, I can no longer hear the balloon noises. I googled for a way to fix this and found many others having t hff e same issue after the town hall upgrade. title: Music too loud after town hall upgrade and no way to adjust. always night time for those who work.

author: Hey It’s Ya Boy
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2020
review_content: Several years ago, I bought and played Animal Crossing: New Leaf on my 3DS. I could never fully invest myself in it, and even though I would come back to it, and replay it in an attempt to understand what people liked about it so much, I eventually dropped it.When this game was announced, I was never planning on buying it. It was only around release time that I started to take an interest in it, and I eventually bought it, thinking it would be different than NL. I was correct in this thinking. I have invested over 175 hours into the game thus far. I think what sets it apart from NL is the level of customization that it includes. The ability to customize your entire island, including the location of resident’s houses, shops, and anything else you can think of (with the exception of Resident Services). Terraforming is also a very neat feature which allows you to make some truly impressive island layouts with ponds, rivers, waterfalls, cliffs, and ramps. You can also fully customize your character from their eyes, hair, skin colors, etc. It’s a far cry from the presets of previous games.The biggest and most annoying drawback would have to be that you can’t craft multiple items at once. If you want to craft 50 fish baits to catch that rare fish you’ve been wanting, you’ll have to spend a good 15 minutes at the DIY bench just pressing buttons over, and over, and over again.A nice feature to add would also be the ability to fast-forward through certain dialogue options, like talking to Blathers when you want to donate or have him assess something.It’s a great little game with a few drawbacks, but I’d say it’s definitely worth it’s price.
title: Huge Improvements to the Animal Crossing Formula

author: Ben
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2020
review_content: The title is a bit exaggerative. I didn't buy them both for myself, I bought the digital copy for myself on launch day, and have been playing on my island for nearing on ten months. I bought my most recent copy for my step-nephew for the holidays and I hope that once I give it to him he will seriously appreciate this game as I did playing the Animal Crossing games since Wild World.There's new elements to the game that significantly changed the Animal Crossing formula such as "DIY," which is just ACNH's term for crafting, the player character and villagers live on a deserted island, which you can now add furniture and rearrange homes to make it as lively and as organized as the player chooses, rather than a small town, in which you stuck with what you have, and couldn't change as much. Same as the previous installments, you can catch bugs and fish, dig for fossils, and in the newest update you can dive under the sea to catch sea creatures like in New Leaf, this game is overall one of the best modern Animal Crossing games we have gotten.That isn't to say this game is perfect. On launch day, there was no way to save your island to the internet, it could only be saved to the console itself, so if you were to move a Switch profile to another Nintendo Switch, and that was the only profile that played the game, you would lose all of your progress and it would he difficult and sometimes downright impossible to get back. Luckily this problem has been somewhat solved, but that left a bad taste in my mouth that the developers didn't consider what certain players experiences might have been. And that isn't the only problem with ACNH, but that was one of the biggest ones.Overall, if you think the player would like lax gameplay and creating your own goals rather than them being shown to you, this is probably a good game for you to pick up. If not, you can try to play it anyway, but I'm unsure if you'll appreciate the concept, which is also okay. Everyone's different. There's no perfect game for everyone.
title: I purchased this game twice and was satisfied both times.

author: SouthernPeach
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 14, 2021
review_content: The actual gameplay is simple. If you have ever played a larger game like World of Warcraft or Skyrim where crafting was just supposed to be a very (very) small part of gameplay but you spent all your time, bag space and bank space getting and storing materials...this is the game for you. Gathering crafting materials and then crafting is big chunk of how you’ll spend your time in game! (ADHD finally has SQUIRREL!! lol) There are times in the game when you’re waiting on something, like a building or materials respawn and during those times it will help to have a routine for daily activities. Fishing, shell collecting, farming woods, etc.Easy game to learn, even for me at 40+ yrs of age. There are game guides available for free on the internet which makes learning the game easy AND fun.Now, with all of that being said, this is not a game that you can start playing, grind out levels (there really aren’t any), make it to end levels and then "beat" the game. It will take some commitment, patience and time to get to where you have "beat" the game.This is a highly entertaining game for me and there is plenty to do, so it’s fairly easy to have fun with and I’m very happy with my purchase!
title: Entertaining and satisfying...

author: Ashton Doherty
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on April 1, 2020
review_content: From the adult single player perspective, this is the most involved version of Animal Crossing to date. Customization is virtually limitless and it introduces the option of terraforming the land itself. The ways you can build up your island stretch beyond the imagination. New Horizons introduces crafting, seasonal items and recipes, download-based events that last longer than one day so they really feel like holidays, and advanced character customization right from the beginning. I'll break down the pros and cons at the end of my review.I think there is some confusion, especially for people new to the series, regarding how multiplayer works.Animal Crossing has always been a ONE town/island game, with the option for up to 3 more players to share that land, since the idea is that you'd be building your oasis together. Unfortunately the co-op in this version is lackluster, especially since the Switch is marketed as a more social console than others Nintendo has released in the past. The multiplayer in a single town is, plain and simple, not worth it. Like others have said, you can really only play follow the leader and collect things together. It kinda defeats the purpose of true multiplayer mode, which is much more comprehensive in the console-to-console visiting (as it has been in the past as well). The true fun in multiplayer for ACNH is in visiting other islands entirely, seeing how they have built and organized their land, and exchanging exclusive fruits and rare items with each other (not to mention hitting each other endlessly with nets). If you have multiple consoles in your house or have friends with their own Switch and copy of the game, you'll find LOTS of enjoyment in the multiplayer.PROS:- Character customization is great. Skin tone is finally a choice, alongside many hairstyles and colors which become unlockable over time. Many basics are included right from the beginning and can be changed whenever you'd like.- Able Sisters is a true boutique. Every day they have a large stock of clothing, including many color variants. You can also layer multiple facial accessories.- Designing is a joy. The designer feature seems to "read" what shapes and colors you use and will round out sharp edges. This means any user-designed paths, stones, and clothing will blend in seamlessly with the soft graphics of the game. You can choose from different styles of clothing while you design, such as sweaters, robes, bowler hats, and beanies. Additionally, there is now an option for transparent patterns. No more having 4 different stepping stone designs for every season so the grass around your rocks will blend in with the natural grass. There is also a "face paint" option, which is very useful for equipping your character with eyebrows, freckles, etc.- Nook Miles ticket islands are worthwhile to work for, and allow you access to more crafting resources that you may have exhausted out of your own island for the day. They also have a chance to spawn rare creatures, Bell rocks, foreign fruits, and hybrid flowers.- The graphics have received a huge update. Everything in the game, including returning items, has a new model and looks better than ever. Wind rustles trees, flowers, and even items that have hanging bits, such as the clothing racks.- Your storage system is automatically built into your home, and home design is streamlined into a drag and drop menu for easy decorating.- Being able to put any item outdoors and build pathways has transformed the possibilities in this game. You can make so many things: trading booths, actual gardens, shop stands, playgrounds, cafes, spas, raffles, relay races, you name it. I've seen an incredible amount of creativity in the first week of release.- You can choose where your new villagers will move, and move any building at any time, save for the plaza and Resident Services within it. There is a cost involved but it's well worth it if you hate where something is placed.- So far I have not yet reached the cap on constructing inclines and bridges. You can make a bunch.CONS:- Terraforming takes a bit to unlock and can be finicky to navigate. You may think you're standing on the correct tile to place a path or build a cliff, but you'll be pushed to another tile, have to erase, and try again. Understanding where you are in space is just a little more difficult because the layout of your island looks a lot less geometric than it did in the past, but overall that is still a positive. Just makes terraforming a bit harder.- In the 3DS New Leaf: Welcome Amiibo version, scanning an Amiibo card would allow you to replace any resident villager with the one on your card, and they would move in the next day. In this version, scanning a card will put the villager in your campsite, but you must invite them to move in THREE times before they will agree. It just seems like a bit of work, since any random villager you find on a Nook Miles Island will move in the very next day after you ask them.- This is my big one: Blathers' museum, while changed drastically to be incredibly beautiful, no longer displays facts for donated creatures. Reading a sign will just give you the name of the creature and donor. To learn about a creature, you need to have it in your inventory and give it to Blathers under the request to learn more. This feels like a huge hit to the museum which is already lacking features. It seemed like they removed the one main reason to visit.- No sign of my favorite NPCs, Katrina (fortune teller) and Brewster (cafe owner). Hopefully, though, there are plans to implement them at a later date, as the game receives regular updates.Overall, this is a staple in any casual gamer's collection, a great intro for anyone new to the series, and something pleasant to pick up whenever and wherever, regardless of whether you have countless hours or just a few minutes. Give it a try!
